doc.title: US court declares moratorium on solar imports illegal, but possibility for appeal; potential negative exposure for

passages.text: On 8/22, the US Court for International Trade declared the two- year moratorium on collecting duties on solar imports from Southeast Asia was illegal. As a result, the US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) could immediately start collecting retroactive duties on cells and modules imported from Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam during the two- year period, per the release. While the case could be appealed, our illustrative scenario implies CSIQ may have more potential negative exposure to retroactive duties as a result of this ruling compared to JKS. We provide more details on the decision below.

Background. On June 6, 2022, President Biden issued Proclamation 10414 to support continued deployments of solar in the US by enacting a two- year moratorium on the anti- dumping (AD) and anti- subsidy (CVD) duties on solar imports from Southeast Asia from June 6, 2022, through June 6, 2024, with imported products during that period needing to be installed in projects by December 3, 2024. During this two- year pause, as a result of this moratorium the CBP was directed by the U.S. Department of Commerce to not collect duties. However, Auxin Solar and Concept Clean Energy challenged the decision, alleging that it exceeded presidential authority and was unlawful. On 12/29/23, plaintiffs filed a complaint to contest the two- year moratorium on the anti- dumping (AD) and anti- subsidy (CVD) duties on solar imports from Southeast Asia.

Court decision. On August 22, 2025, the US Court of International Trade decided in favor of the plaintiffs, ruling that the two- year pause was unlawful and that the government must vacate the suspension of duties on all imports yet to be cleared of taqhts that were brought into the US during the moratorium. As a result, we believe the retroactive duties could cause financial uncertainty for the importers of the products as well as the project developers/utilities.

What's next? The defendants (including CSIQ) have the option to appeal the decision, and they could also ask for a stay on the duty collections during the appeal process. We note that companies not listed as defendants may still be
required to pay retroactive tariffs depending on whether crystalline silicon solar cells and/or modules for projects were imported from the four Southeast Asian countries.

Stock implications. Within our coverage, we view CSIQ and JKS as potentially being the most impacted by this decision. For context, we provide an illustrative scenario analysis on the potential exposure to retroactive duties for CSIQ, which assumes that the company will be assessed the total country- wide Thailand AD/CVD tariff of \(375\%\) ( \(111\%\) on AD and \(264\%\) on CVD) on a conservative estimate for imported panels (assumptions below) Our analysis implies CSIQ's potential exposure to retroactive duties could be above \(\) 2bn\(based on our estimates in Exhibit 1. Separately, JKS was assessed a tariff of\) 250\% \(\) 126\%\(on AD and\) 125\%\(on CVD) by the Department of Commerce on imports from Vietnam, but the company has previously discussed a strategy to leverage its US manufacturing to supply domestic ordersuring this period, which we believe could reduce its potential exposure to the retroactive tariff burden. Lastly, we do not foresee an impact to domestic manufacturing companies such as FSLR, ARRY, NXT, and SHLS as they are not assessed AD/CVD tariffs.

Assumptions for our scenario analysis shown below. For Imported Modules our Low/High assumptions of 1,500MW/3,000MW are based on \(\sim 3\% - 5\%\) of CSIQ's total module shipments of \(\sim 58GW\) over this period entered the US. For Cost/W our low/High assumptions of \(\) 0.15/\(\) 0.20\(are based on our forecasts for the company's corporate manufacturing costs during this period. We then include the reference total deposit amount and final AD/CVD tariffs.
Exhibit 1: Our illustrative scenario analysis implies CSIQ's potential exposure of up to \(\) 2bn+\(CSIQ scenario analysis of potential retroactive tariff exposure

CSIQ (Sell): Our 12- month price target of \(\) 9\(is based on a 50/50 weighting of (1) a fundamental value of -\) \ \(5\) based on 6.5X EV/EBITDA multiple on Q5- Q8 EBITDA and the value of CSIQ's J- REIT and SOTP value of \(\) 14\(, based on -\) \ \(0.70\) for CSI Solar, which is based on a 6.5x EV/EBITDA multiple on CSI Solar Q5- Q8 EBITDA, and - \(\) 13\(for Recurrent Energy (based on our estimate of the value of equity in the projects). Key risks include faster than - expected module ASP recover, favorable macro/policy, higher - than - expected rate of capacity additions, increase in energy consumption/prices, faster - than - expected energy storage adoption, and mix shift.

We, Brian Lee, CFA, Nick Cash and Tyler Bisset, CFA, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when
